title: Scott Addict Gravel gets Dangerholm-ed to create most custom, integrated carbon gravel bike ever!
content:
Every time we catch wind of a new Dangerholm project we can’t wait to see how crazy custom it will end up, and this latest Scott Addict Gravel project bike certainly doesn’t disappoint. To be fair Gustav Gullholm – the wild man behind the knife and short jorts – had a more integrated starting point working with the recently debuted Addict Gravel. But true to form, he was quick to break out the knives and start scraping away every extra gram of paint. And while this custom build was less “destructive” and “warranty-voiding” than most of his projects, there’s no shortage of beautiful details, unique solutions, and even a few prototypes tucked into the build…

Super-custom Scott Addict Gravel – Dangerholm edition

It’s been less than two months since Gustav Dangerholm-ed his Scott Scale XC hardtail into a flat bar mountain biker’s gravel bike. But when Scott debuted their all-new Addict Gravel bike literally one day later, it was simply a matter of time until that new integrated aero carbon gravel got the real custom treatment, taking Scott’s idea of “Tuned” to new levels.

We’ve been keeping up with Dangerholm as he worked on the Scott Addict Gravel project – his first drop bar custom – and while his projects often aim for lofty superlight “World’s Lightest” or “ultra-integrated” goals, he said this bike was already light & integrated when he started. So instead, this became a project about “looks, speed and sheer performance”.

pro sunset photoshoot by Andreas Timfält

It’s still no heavyweight. At 7.13kg / 15.72lb complete including pedals, that’s a full 1kg lighter than Scott’s lightest 8700€ complete Tuned build without pedals. Just don’t ask how much the Dangerholm edition would cost you! Your bank account doesn’t even want to know.

Prototypes, hacks & ultralight upgrades

Looking at the rarest of the rare details on the Scott Addict Gravel Dangerholm edition, a couple of lightweight prototypes pop out. Those 3D-printed titanium Titanum MyTi Ultra clipless mountain bike pedals certainly stand out. Weighing just 101g for the pair on Dangerholm’s trusty scale and only 40g more for their pair of 2-bolt ti cleats, we believe what Titanum told us last March when they went to Kickstarter calling them the “lightest ever for any discipline”. While these are technically still prototypes, after their successful crowdfunding campaign this year, consumer availability looks likely to be ‘coming soon’.

Another set of suitably drool-worthy prototypes are the new set of Trickstuff Strada flat mount brake calipers with new titanium-back brake pads… because why not, right? Beyond just being pretty & shiny, the revised two-piston calipers are designed with larger pad openings for improved pad clearance with these Trickstuff Dachle or other rotors, and are available to work with either Shimano or SRAM levers. Want to see the Shimano C22 version? Check out our Eurobike coverage of Trickstuff brake updates.

The SRAM XX1 Eagle mechanical rear derailleur started life as a pretty common, if fancy mountain bike component. But Gustav took it over the top first by giving it a straightforwardly expensive CermicSpeed OSPW oversized ceramic bearing pulley upgrade, and then replacing the heavy stock derailleur body with ultralight Hopp carbon upgrades. The result is not much original left of the SRAM mech outside of the P-link and clutch.

photo by Andreas Timfält

Interestingly, Dangerholm opted for the weight savings and simplicity of a SRAM mechanical shift drivetrain. But to get the wide gearing he wanted, it was time to get creative. Up front, a SRAM Force 1x left lever joins a mechanical shift Red right lever, converted from 11-speed road to 12-speed mountain indexing thanks to the Ratio upgrade inside. That let Gustav opt for a 1×12 drivetrain with a 46 x 10-46T gear spread.

photo by Andreas Timfält

Tech details

photo by Andreas Timfält

The size 56cm Scott Addict Gravel Tuned frame does get a few mildly dangerous Dangerholm customizations including four new rivnut mounts installed in custom carbon-reinforced areas for a future integrated bikepacking bag setup. The Addict Gravel Tuned fork appears to have escaped unscathed. Both frame & fork do get light alloy Carbon-Ti thru-axle upgrades.

The proprietary carbon Syncros Duncan SL Aero seatpost gets its own two new custom bikepacking bag mounts. We’re curious to see what a Dangerholm custom bikepacking back setup will look like.

photo by Andreas Timfält

photo by Andreas Timfält

The cockpit is also surprisingly stock, as Syncros just debuted the new fully-integrated iC SL gravel bar for the new gravel bike. It uses the standard Acros for Syncros headset, but sheds a gram or two with an Italian Extralite expander inside.

Back into the rare lightweight components is the Schmolke SL79 carbon saddle that Gustav swears is comfortable.

photo by Andreas Timfält

The drivetrain is a bit of a unique mix, pairing a direct mount Garabuk chainring on a SRAM Red DUB carbon crankset to a Rotor 12-speed cassette via a SRAM XO1 mountain bike chain.

photo by Andreas Timfält

photo by Andreas Timfält

Rounding off the custom build is a total custom wheelbuild. Dangerholm started with a set of light 404-410g German carbon Radsporttechnik Mueller MGRX 45mm deep, 25mm internal tubeless rims laced into Tune’s lightest Prince & Princess carbon-reinforced hubs with ceramic bearings and carbon endcaps.

The entire bike was custom painted by hand by Gustav himself – a self-described amateur painter who’s “still learning”- finished in the same Zanzibar Brown metallic paint you might find on an old Volvo or a fancy modern Range Rover. While a nude, bare carbon finish is always lighter, he said that beautiful brown paint only added about 18-20g per rim, a penalty he was happy to accept in the name of shiny goodness.

photo by Andreas Timfält

That’s it. Now Gustav is out riding his latest ultra-custom Scott Addict Gravel, Dangerholm edition creation around Norway and Sweden hunting gravel roads (not hard to find it seems.)

Now the question just remains, how loose will this technically-skilled mountain biker get on drop bars? And what’s his super-custom, Dangerholm bikepacking setup going to look like?

photo by Andreas Timfält
author: Cory Benson
